item.title:
R to @0xstark: 19. @hyperdrive_box is an AMM for fixed rate yield markets, built on top of yield sources like stETH & sDAI.
This lets users earn fixed rate yield, or lock in fixed rates on existing positions from lending protocols, all while LP positions never mature.
item.dc:creator: @0xstark
item.description:
19. @hyperdrive_box is an AMM for fixed rate yield markets, built on top of yield sources like stETH & sDAI.

This lets users earn fixed rate yield, or lock in fixed rates on existing positions from lending protocols, all while LP positions never mature.

item.title:
RT by @0xstark: We‚Äôre excited to announce the 2025 Decentralized Tech Summit, which @TheDRC_ will be hosting in partnership with @pro_jectliberty!
The summit will take place on April 2nd at the National Press Club in Washington D.C.
With growing alignment between Congress and the Administration on the need for comprehensive blockchain policy ‚Äî and the potential for significant regulatory developments this session ‚Äî the 2025 summit will focus on blockchain decentralization, emerging policy frameworks, and the broader ecosystem of decentralized applications.
See why this year is so vital, and apply below üëá

item.title:
RT by @0xstark: 1/ @chinmaydoteth asked me on FC if L2s with centralized sequencers are less decentralized than Solana
Centralization isn‚Äôt binary. What matters is the properties it gives you
A centralized sequencer can‚Äôt steal your funds as long as the exit window is open
Let me explain üßµ

item.title:
RT by @0xstark: L1 is scaling.
A big shoutout to all the developers working on EIP-4444 (history expiry), statelessness (see the new binary tree EIP! https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9257 ), client efficiency upgrades, and other features that will make higher L1 gas limits decentralization-friendly.
item.dc:creator: @VitalikButerin
item.description:
L1 is scaling.

A big shoutout to all the developers working on EIP-4444 (history expiry), statelessness (see the new binary tree EIP! github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pul‚Ä¶ ), client efficiency upgrades, and other features that will make higher L1 gas limits decentralization-friendly.

item.title:
RT by @0xstark: my summary fwiw:
Agree: - cross-L2 interop is broken today ü§ù - we can and should move much faster ‚úÖ - goal is simple ‚Äì moving assets between chains with zero friction üèÜ
Disagree: - we should put more resources into solving only "cluster interop"
imo the most ambitious + high leverage thing we can do is to bring the clusters together to find a pragmatic and efficient path to solving interop (months not years). It's a challenge. But can be achieved if driven by a balance of pragmatism and desire to achieve ambitious things for Ethereum. We can / must do it all.
PS: I think we actually mostly all on the same page here. But Twitter makes it seem like we aren't :) Which can drive a wedge into interop. Lots of respect and appreciation for Uma, Succinct, and everyone jumping into interop efforts!
item.dc:creator: @rudolf6_
item.description:
my summary fwiw:

Agree:
- cross-L2 interop is broken today ü§ù
- we can and should move much faster ‚úÖ
- goal is simple ‚Äì moving assets between chains with zero friction üèÜ

Disagree:
- we should put more resources into solving only "cluster interop"

imo the most ambitious + high leverage thing we can do is to bring the clusters together to find a pragmatic and efficient path to solving interop (months not years). It's a challenge. But can be achieved if driven by a balance of pragmatism and desire to achieve ambitious things for Ethereum. We can / must do it all.

PS: I think we actually mostly all on the same page here. But Twitter makes it seem like we aren't :) Which can drive a wedge into interop. Lots of respect and appreciation for Uma, Succinct, and everyone jumping into interop efforts!

item.title:
RT by @0xstark: 1/ Centralized control of networks has consequence ‚Äî Big Tech, Big Banks, and Big AI control public discourse, financial access, and even information.
Decentralization eliminates control, but it needs to be incentivized. Here's how. üëá

item.title:
R to @0xstark: 18. @Nounsdao auctions one generative NFT (a Noun), every 24h, with proceeds going to a DAO controlled by Noun owners.
@Nounsdao funds creative projects like films and art, and public goods like onchain infra (e.g. prop house) and real-world infra (like schools in Uganda).
item.dc:creator: @0xstark
item.description:
18. @Nounsdao auctions one generative NFT (a Noun), every 24h, with proceeds going to a DAO controlled by Noun owners.

@Nounsdao funds creative projects like films and art, and public goods like onchain infra (e.g. prop house) and real-world infra (like schools in Uganda).

item.title:
R to @0xstark: 17. @basepaint_xyz is a shared pixel canvas on @base where a community creates art together for 24 hours.
Then, the art is minted as an NFT where artists earn 90% of profits, proportionate to the number of pixels they contributed.
item.dc:creator: @0xstark
item.description:
17. @basepaint_xyz is a shared pixel canvas on @base where a community creates art together for 24 hours.

Then, the art is minted as an NFT where artists earn 90% of profits, proportionate to the number of pixels they contributed.

item.title:
New experiment for @ethereum: community guest threads!
Ethereum's community is one of its great strengths, and @ethereum should be a platform to showcase the best of it.
Thanks @sassal0x for writing the first one, more to come soon.
item.dc:creator: @0xstark
item.description:
New experiment for @ethereum: community guest threads!

Ethereum's community is one of its great strengths, and @ethereum should be a platform to showcase the best of it.

Thanks @sassal0x for writing the first one, more to come soon.

item.title:
RT by @0xstark: .@drakefjustin's work is incredibly valuable to ethereum's future, especially those of us who care about keeping the protocol decentralized and secure long-term and fighting against the zoo of technical bloat.
The beam chain roadmap got criticism for the "2029" date, but what that criticism misses is that the beam chain roadmap is a completely separate and parallel workstream from the work that is happening already to meet users' needs in the short term (basically, scaling blobs, where @dankrad has for years played a leading and invaluable part)
In 2025, we need blobs (and L1 cost reductions like EIP-4444). In 2026, we need more blobs. @fradamt @dankrad and many others are heroes for pushing forward the research here. By 2030, we need other things:
* Long-term robust economics * Long-term robust staking decentralization * A clean and simple protocol, something worthy of a chain that aspires to be a neutral global base layer. This means zeroing out huge amounts of technical bloat * Security (see also: https://verified-zkevm.org/ , which @alexanderlhicks has done a lot to get to its current state) * Fully verifying light clients that can work on even the smallest devices * Quantum-resistance (BTW this item is also one of the big reasons why "no AA, just keep EOAs + 7702" is NOT a valid option for ethereum long-term, we have to actually abstract the verification function as well, eg. see EIP-7701)
The beam chain roadmap delivers on all of these items.
It is a necessary complement to all of the important short-term work that we need to get done.
And in addition to the beam chain, @drakefjustin has been invaluable in helping the verified-zkevm team spin up, as well as all kinds of other cryptography and ZK initiatives.
We have excellent researchers and I am very proud of them. (And also excellent non-researchers)
item.dc:creator: @VitalikButerin
item.description:
.@drakefjustin's work is incredibly valuable to ethereum's future, especially those of us who care about keeping the protocol decentralized and secure long-term and fighting against the zoo of technical bloat.

The beam chain roadmap got criticism for the "2029" date, but what that criticism misses is that the beam chain roadmap is a completely separate and parallel workstream from the work that is happening already to meet users' needs in the short term (basically, scaling blobs, where @dankrad has for years played a leading and invaluable part)

In 2025, we need blobs (and L1 cost reductions like EIP-4444). In 2026, we need more blobs. @fradamt @dankrad and many others are heroes for pushing forward the research here. By 2030, we need other things:

* Long-term robust economics
* Long-term robust staking decentralization
* A clean and simple protocol, something worthy of a chain that aspires to be a neutral global base layer. This means zeroing out huge amounts of technical bloat
* Security (see also: verified-zkevm.org/ , which @alexanderlhicks has done a lot to get to its current state)
* Fully verifying light clients that can work on even the smallest devices
* Quantum-resistance (BTW this item is also one of the big reasons why "no AA, just keep EOAs + 7702" is NOT a valid option for ethereum long-term, we have to actually abstract the verification function as well, eg. see EIP-7701)

The beam chain roadmap delivers on all of these items.

It is a necessary complement to all of the important short-term work that we need to get done.

And in addition to the beam chain, @drakefjustin has been invaluable in helping the verified-zkevm team spin up, as well as all kinds of other cryptography and ZK initiatives.

We have excellent researchers and I am very proud of them. (And also excellent non-researchers)
